sekki.description: The first hints of an approaching spring. Eastern winds melt the ice on the ground, fish appear in their icy ponds and the bush warblers start singing in the mountains.
Snow melts away, mist lingers in the air, and the grasses begin to sprouting. Trees release their first buds as the ground fills with water.
That time of year when the first bugs surface from their hibernation. Caterpillars start their transformation to butterflies.
When winter is gone and spring starts. Sparrows begin to nest in the trees. Cherry blossoms start to bloom. Heavy rains bring distant thunder.
Shortly after the equinox, when the swallows return home and the geese fly north. The first rainbows of the season appear.
Reeds sprout by the rivers and rice seedlings grow in the fields after the last frost has passed. Peonies bloom in the wilderness.
The songs of summer begin. Frogs start their singing, and birds chirp in the forests. Worms surface from underground, bamboo shoots begin to sprout.
When flowers and plants start to come out. Silkworms start feasting on mulberry leaves, and the safflower workers start their picking. Wheat begins to ripen.
The time of year when people start to seed the soil. Praying mantises hatch. Rotten grass become home to fireflies. The plums become more yellow.
The longest days of the year. The sun reaches its highest point, accompanied by mist and rains. A sweet woodsy dryness hangs in the air. Irises bloom and crow-dippers start to sprout.
The summer heat begins. Warm winds blow, lotus' blossom, and young hawks are learning to fly.
Summer heat is at its strongest, followed by great rains. The air is thick and humid and the trees are busy making seeds.
The first signs of autumn can be seen. Cooler winds blow, and thick fogs roll through the hills in the morning.
The heat of summer has been forgotten. The rice has ripened and cotton flowers are in bloom.
When drops of dew can be seen on the grass. Swallows leave for the year, and the wagtails sing.
Day and night are of equal length. Farmers drain their fields and insects hide underground.
Temperatures begin dropping. The geese return for the winter. Crickets chirp for the last time in the year.
The first frosts. Rains disappear as the maple leaves and ivy turn yellow.
When the winter season starts. Land begins to freeze, rivers and streams shortly to follow.
Light snowfall appears. Northern winds have blown the last leaves from the trees.
The cold sets in. Bears are hibernating in their dens, and the salmon have swam upstream. Nature is quiet.
When days are the shortest in the whole year. Deer in the mountains shed their antlers, and wheat sprouts rest underneath the snow.
Winter chills start as the temperature quickly drops. Pheasant calls can be heard in the forest
Temperatures drop low and the chill deepens. Ice thickens on the streams. Hens huddle together and begin laying eggs.
